properties.description: Example: ASC29001
properties.title: ASC Number

properties.description: The number of the box that contains your negative envelope. Note that there is a space before and after the "/". i.e. 1974-002 / 095 (Note: we're missing identifier_other)
properties.title: Box number

properties.description: Negative envelopes OCCASIONALLY have multiples. Elvis has at least 3 negative envelopes with the same title. i.e. Envelope 1 of 3
properties.title: Identifier Other

properties.description:
For .pdf, always use the title written on the envelope that contains the negative. Use a space colon space to separate information as it appears on the envelope. If there is a NOT USED or COPY stamped on your envelope, enter [not used] or [copy] in square brackets one space after your title. i.e. Colonial Tavern : Renovation : Waitress Contest [copy]

For .tif if you are a Bib Services student "[to be supplied]"

For .tif if you are an Archives/Bib Services staff member then you will be creating a title based on the content of the .tif image file
properties.title: Title

properties.description: If this is a TIF, the value here should be: Title based on content of image
properties.title: Supplied title source

properties.description: For .pdf only. This field is used when some words in title written on the envelope are abbreviated. Put the full form of abbreviated words in square brackets. i.e. If “Can. Imperial Bank of Commerce” is written on the envelope, enter “Can. Imperial Bank of Commerce” in title, and “[Canadian] Imperial Bank of Commerce [CIBC]” in title_alternative field. Note: This field can contain either full or part of title depends on how title is abbreviated, and you can always check the Abbreviation & full form mapping list for full spelling of words.
properties.title: Sub Title

properties.description: If [not used] is displayed on the object, please enter [not used].
properties.title: [not used]

properties.description: The negative envelope title that the image is associated with.
properties.title: Forms part of (TIF)

properties.description: Toronto Telegram photographic negatives, S00054
properties.title: Forms part of (PDF)

properties.description:
For .pdf describe the contents of the .pdf of the assignment envelope, any loose sheets of photographer's instructions, the number of contact sheets and the Assignment envelope's title i.e. "File consists of front and back of negative envelope, front and back of loose sheet, and five contact sheets. Assignment: Dirty Shames : Singing Group"
Field not used for .tifs
properties.title: Description

properties.description: Enter the surname of the person on the order form. i.e. O’Brian. If you are scanning for archival preservation purposes, enter “ASC Red Dot”
properties.title: Researcher

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Type

properties.description: Enter the name of the photographer on the assignment envelope. i.e. Sale If you are not sure of the spelling of the photographer’s name, double-check the Tele Staff listing. If there is no name on the assignment envelope, enter: [Telegram staff] using the square brackets.
properties.title: Name

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Role

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Type

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Name

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Role

properties.description: Date the photographer wrote on the assignment envelope. This date will likely be handwritten on the back of the envelope. Always write this date without punctuation in the following format (the month in longhand): 18 January 1967 Sometimes the information is incomplete! When it is, use the date information on the front of the envelope, but put in square brackets. i.e. if there is no year on back, but it is on the front, you would put 18 January [1967]. If back is blank, use entire date on front in square brackets, i.e. [18 January 1967].
properties.title: Date Issued (free text)

properties.description: Date the negative was used. This is stamped on the front of the envelope near the title. Use format YYYY-MM-DD. (i.e. 1965-02-11) If there is a “NOT USED” or “COPY” stamp on the front of the envelope, enter only the year and month that was handwritten on the back of the envelope. i.e. 1955-04
properties.title: Date Issued (iso)

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Publisher

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Country

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Place

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Type of Resource

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Genre

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Language

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Form

properties.description: Always measure the dimensions of the negative in cm. Note that cm is only typed once in the example below. 1 photograph : b&w negative; 5.3 x 3.6 cm Glass plate negative: 1 photograph : b&w negative, on glass ; 5.3 x 5.3 cm There is ONE exception. If you’re scanning 35 mm film, don’t measure it, just put 35 mm, as shown here: 1 photograph : b&w negative; 35 mm
properties.title: Format

properties.description: Put neg number in round brackets. Count the number of negatives in the assignment folder for the ‘out of __ in assignment.’ i.e. One neg (5-5A) scanned out of 30 in assignment. If the total no. of negs. Is not written on the envelope, you have to count them! Note: DPI and other info is automatically captured.
properties.title: Relation

properties.description: If you’re scanning or using negatives from a Red Dot Envelope, put the ASC# of the Envelope in this field. Also refer to the ASC Already Scanned Workflow if you’re dealing with an item that has been previously scanned. Note: Julia also uses this field to note related items.
properties.title: Related material

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: Title (Finding aid)

properties.description: Ignore.
properties.title: url (Finding aid)

properties.description: Please derive the subject from the assignment envelope, or, the general subject heading as determined in the finding aid. If you are not sure, look at the pdf file copy of the finding aid and locate the subject heading.
properties.title: Subject

properties.description: Name of a country, i.e. a political entity considered a country.
properties.title: Country

properties.description: Includes first order political divisions called provinces within a country, e.g. in Canada.
properties.title: Province

properties.description: Includes regions that have status as a jurisdiction, usually incorporating more than one first level jurisdiction.
properties.title: Region

properties.description: Name of the largest local administrative unit in various countries, e.g. England.
properties.title: County

properties.description: Name of an inhabited place incorporated as a city, town, etc.
properties.title: City

properties.description: Name of a smaller unit within a populated place, e.g., neighborhoods, parks, or streets.
properties.title: City Section

properties.description: Please put coordinates in decimal format: 43.653333, -79.383889 -- NOT degree format 43°39′12″N 079°23′02″W
students can enter this information from the drop-down list

index.key: Photograph now in public domain. For citation information or to obtain high resolution image, contact ascproj@yorku.ca or see Toronto Telegram FAQ.

options.index: Photograph taken by Toronto Telegram photographer before 1962?

index.key: Copyright owned by York University. For permission to publish or other copyright questions, contact ascproj@yorku.ca

options.index: Photograph taken by Toronto Telegram photographer on/or after 1962?

index.key: Copyright owned by photographer. For more information see Toronto Telegram FAQ.
Copyright owned by wire service. For more information contact, ascproj@yorku.ca

properties.title: Usage rights
